reviews.review_msg: Dr. Perkin's is the only professor that I have ever encountered, at a university level, that picks favourites among her students. I was shocked and disgusted. While her lectures are engaging and the assignments suit the classes material, her arrogance and lack of social skills takes away from the courses energy.

Charmaine has a very unique way of conducting a class. At times I down right could not stand the course, I think this gets confused with the quality of the professor. She holds people to a very high standard, I found when I went to talk to her she wouldn't hand out answers. I really respect this professor, and her way of teaching grew on me.

I've taken 3 classes Dr. Perkins and have never had a prof as helpful and caring. However, she does not hands us everything on a platter... & this is where she gets her bad rep (students believe they are entitled to all answers and undeserving grades). but she does not mark their work. She is very helpful during office hours & always extends it
Unapproachable, super condescending and straight up rude. Her expectations were way to high for a third year course. Avoid her at all costs!!!!!!!

Dr. Perkins is the toughest grader I have come across at SFU. She does not give great feedback, she is not helpful when going to see her in her office hours and honestly I found her disrespectful and harsh. In lecture, she tells the class how horribly everyone did on their papers, and just yells to read the textbook. Skips slides, unprepared.

I feel like the only way to get a decent grade on her written assignments is to have the writing level of a grad student in an undergraduate course. This is the hardest I have ever worked in any course and I feel like I'm only going to get a c- if I'm lucky.

This should be a 4-5 credit course. Takes two months to give you approval for your research project on top of weekly discussions, group projects, a paper to write, a final exam and a project that takes weeks to complete. Prime example of giving way too much work in order to justify your useless research style and try to make it seem legitimate.
One of my favorite teachers at sfu. Very inspiring and actually cares for your success. The challenge experienced in her classes is what should be expected in University. Big thumbs up.

This is my second time taking a class with Dr. Perkins. She is helpful, understanding and very clear on her guidelines. As long as you follow her guidelines, you will succeed. Favourite professor at SFU! I would highly recommend Dr. Perkins to everyone - she shows true passion in teaching, which is why she is such an amazing professor!

One of the hardest classes I've taken at SFU. One 30 minute presentation, weekly assignments, two papers - one was 10 pages and the other was 20 (you had to conduct your own research study). Charmaine is condescending at first but if you meet her outside of class she is quite helpful. Extremely hard marker, though.

Dr. Perkins is a very caring prof that wants to see her students succeed. If you put time and effort into the course and visit her office hours, you will do well! Will definitely take another class with her.

Really regretting this class, and were barely into it. She constantly feels the need (literally every lecture) to make fun of students. She mocks the class saying we think we know everything and that we think were experienced researchers, yet shes the only person Ive heard say this. Im sad I spent my hard earned $ on this course with her.
Very interesting class. If you really want to learn then take her. You need to work hard but this prof is really helpful and wants to see her student succeed.
Excellent Professor, very helpful and genuinely interested in supporting everyone. Very reasonable and I would take a another class with Dr. Perkins in a heart beat.
Charmaine is brilliant and compassionate about everything she teaches.  Although she has high expectations, she is very willing to help out.  Supersmart.
Great TA! Very knowledgeable and helpful. Wish we had more TAs like her
Ryan is awesome! He was really accommodating and very helpful.

Her tutorials are so engaging. I appreciated that she shared tips with the students and showed us ways to work smarter. Her advice for how to plan out our assignments supported me to stay on track and your thorough assignment/presentation feedbacks was also so helpful! Despite the time zone difference, she still provided extra office hours.

Super duper approachable and knowledgeable. She'll never look down on you no matter what questions you ask her. Super helpful and is very good at explaining things in an easy to relate way. Best person to learn qualitative research methods from. She should be a prof!

Best TA ever. Engages students and explains topics in a way that is easy to understand but doesn't talk down to you. Super enthusiastic and always ready to help. Would rearrange schedule to have her be the TA if is was at all possible.

Karm is one the best TA's SFU has to offer and is the best TA I have ever had. Not only is she is approachable, personable and makes everyone feel comfortable, but she is also extremely knowledgeable and great at explaining things. she never didn't have a great answer to a question. Should be a prof!

Such an amazing TA. She knows her stuff and is more than willing to help her students learn. She is extremely accessible, genuinely, caring kind, funny and helpful. By far the best TA I have ever had.

This course is HARD! I really appreciated how she would explain stuff in office hours. Her emails were very short but she went and explained things from the text practically every office hour. If you can, try to get her as a TA!

I just love her as my TA. She answered all my questions, and I had aaalooott of questions lol. This course is hard because you are doing full research but she is very knowledgeable. I found her more helpful than the professor. Attend her office hours and she will help you with all your questions. BEST TA thus far at SFU
would not recommend taking by any means

Hilary is a professor that actually cares about her students and the material she is teaching. She wants her students to be the best researchers they can be. Does this involve work? Yes. Its one of the hardest courses I've taken, but it is well worth it, you learn so much. Hilary was always there to help if I needed it and went above and beyond.
It's a tough class, but manageable. She uploads her expectations onto Canvas and gives a lot of feedback. You definitely need to work for your grade, but you also learn a lot.

She gives little to no information on how to do assignments and expects a perfect research study that can be published in an academic journal. Having high expectations is fine, but not when you give misleading and vague criteria for assignments.

Was super helpful and always ready and willing to put in extra time to assist students. Fantastic T.A. for 321. I was struggling until I went for help. If you're not getting a good grade, go ask! You shouldn't expect higher than a B if you don't try to use her help to better your scores. You can't coast like high school in University!

where do i even begin? hilary is the hardest marking TA i have ever had in my 4 years at SFU. she will criticize every little thing on your paper. she will tell you your paper is wrong from top to bottom. class average on 2 papers were 61% and 63%. she is a harsh, unforgiving, and unhelpful TA. although she marked fairly easy on the in-class exam

Had Logan for CRIM321 in Fall 2017 and he is not just a fair marker but also an awesome TA. He is not intimidating and always ready to help students out. His tutorials were fun, especially considering it was the late on Friday afternoons. Great guy!!

Rebecca is seven levels of awesome. Really interested; hilarious and tries to really engage students.. unfortunately she has an 8 30 am class. Loved her class; the TA's were great and Rebecca made herself extremely accessible. Rebecca made what could have been a painfully boring class interesting and dynamic. Love her.

This prof takes strict to the point of paranoia. This class was a horrible experience and took a significant toll on my mental health. The class was very difficult but the prof made it MUCH worse than it had to be. Disregard the positive reviews, they clearly were written by the prof herself. This is an honest to goodness review. Avoid at all costs

Every lecture I had with Tamie was always just her rambling on about plagiarism and how much she hates it. She's extremely strict when it comes to referencing and in-text citations so make sure you triple check everything. Many students in my class were reported for plagiarism because their citations weren't exactly how she wanted them. Avoid her.

The research assignment will probably take a couple inches off your hairline, so good luck. Overall, not a terrible course. Just another class with Tamie going on and on about plagiarism. Not sure why I even took her again. Also, don't make the mistake I made by doing the research project last minute.

This class was incredibly mentally draining. I have never had such a class before. Try to pick a research topic that is doable so you dont have to resubmit the proposal. Do not procrastinate. I recommend taking no more than 2 other classes. Try to start everything immediately when it is assigned. Data coding is TEDIOUS and LONG, give enough time.

Yes, the final project was difficult. Yes, her grading criteria is very specific. But no other professor would be fit for this class. Individuals who don't do well in this class are students who don't watch her recorded lectures and/or read her instructions. If you are able to keep up with the course content, this class is an easy A.

I will not sugar coat this. This class is pretty brutal and probably the hardest class I have taken in my four years during the CRIM program so far. Super strict marker, ultra strict on plagiarism. Entire sem revolves around a research project which is extremely time consuming and difficult. Avoid taking with more than two other classes. Good luck!

For the proposal and research paper, we were expected to follow the rubrics she provided. She maintains high expectations & strict guidelines, but she is a genuinely caring professor. When students were stressed about other assignments, she gave the whole class an extension! It was still stressful working on the project, but I submitted on time.

I have heard this class is genuinely hard but this prof made it bareable. i love the way she provides extra office hours she litterally tells you want she wants, just follow her rubric THAT IS IT, textbook is mandatory since you have to cite your paper with it but TAKE THIS COURSE W HER WAYYY EASIER and she helps in so many ways and replies fast
very good overall prof, takes everything super by the book, super strict about rules. Almost always starts a lecture talking about plagiarism. As a prof she is very caring.

This prof is extremely strict when it comes to plagiarism, copyright, and marking. Expects everyone to be a PHD student. The course content is very boring and dry, and the amount of work feels overwhelming. DO NOT take this class with more than two other courses, it will be too much. Avoid this prof if possible. You have been warned. Good luck.

Dr. Fennig gives the class her exact grading criteria. If you space out the work (ex. complete the lit. review before receiving permission for data collection) then you will have the time to get everything done well and thoroughly. She is very caring, and accessible outside of class. Beware, she is strict with plagiarism so be sure to triple-check.

Good professor but her criteria for the final assignment is just brutal. So many specifics and updates the syllabus at least 5 times during the course of the semester. Really cares about her students, but just be ready to write the most specific paper you have ever written
I can't believe I pay for my education and I get lectured on what highlighters to use

Very strict on what you should include in your papers, was dreading the lectures because she would talk about how important qualitative studies were and not actually teaching. Dry textbook and additional readings

Tamie is definitely not an easy professor but I find that you can't learn or be inspired when there's an easy prof. The one thing you can rely on when it comes to Tamie is her passion, and her understanding. Hands down the best professor I've ever had, she's specific in what she looks for so there's little room to make mistakes! 100% recommend.
Consistently goes off topic every lecture, probably learned more reading the dry textbook than attending class, sad.
Make sure you have good time management. Tamie is approachable but she gives very vague answers, better off on your own, take an online specific course love

She is a good prof. She cares for her students, but can be strict with plagiarism. She is also ready to work with the students and even move due dates for everyone if it is reasonable. Do not procrastinate with the research paper because it takes an awful lot of time to write - but I feel like my work was cut down because she provided formats.

Dr. Fennig is a great and caring prof. It can be overwhelming with how specific she can be but SHE GIVES YOU A TEMPLATE AND INSTRUCTIONS TO FOLLOW which makes it so easy to format and write your paper. Just do not procrastinate and start your paper early. Email her or go to office hours because she is really approachable.

Dr. Fenning cares for her students but is very strict with marking. For the love of god do not take a course with her unless u want to be lectured about highlighters and how helpful the course is without actually teaching it

if you want a good grade you will have to work for it. if you procrastinate, you will be in trouble with the term paper which is a ridiculous amount of work. pay attention to lectures since she points out the important things.

First time writing here, Tamie was probably the best professor I have ever had. I wish I had taken more courses with her! She goes above and beyond when it comes to helping students be successful in this course. Very passionate, kind and frequently updates FAQs. Always gives detailed feedback to do better. You will not regret taking her class.

I had Tamie during the COVID-19 pandemic and she was so accommodating of the entire class. Gave everyone a one week extension for our final paper and was always there to answer questions via email or her posted FAQ's. Hands down have never met a prof who is as passionate about the subject she teaches and her students success as Tamie is.
Overall an amazing prof who truly does care about students success. Only pet peeve I had was she would always go over class time.

Dr. Fennig goes the extra mile when it comes to ensuring that her students understand the course material by making herself available and posting faq's. Her zeal for qualitative research was reflected in the comprehensiveness of lectures. I would definitely take another class with her again.

Tamie genuinely wants all her students to succeed, and will go the extra mile for you. She is passionate about research and her lectures are packed with real world anecdotes and advice. If you want to do well in this class, start your assignments early and reach out to her in office hours.

Dr. Fennig is the the most kind professor I've ever had at university. She is knowledgeable in the field of criminology, and teaches accordingly. She was able to teach difficult, in-depth material in a way that students were able to understand and retain. In addition, she genuinely cares about her students. I would take any class with Dr. Fennig!

In my 4 years at SFU, this is the first time I've ever rated a prof, but I had to give her 5 stars after taking CRIM 321 w/ Tamie. She made this class a walk in the park, BY FAR the best prof I've had at SFU. She is incredibly caring, kind, understanding and genuinely wants her students to do well in the course. Highly Recommend.

Outstanding, phenomenal, caring, remarkable. I absolutely loved Tamie and her hardwork and passion for her students to succeed is exemplified through her teaching, marking and help she gives. She literally sets you up for success and is an absolute gem. I can go on and on to talk about her. This is my first review of a prof in my 4 years at SFU
One of the nicest profs I ever had. So incredibly helpful and hardworking. However, she has very clear expectations and the class is a lot of work.

I dreaded taking this class because I'm bad at methods but Sarah was so supportive and helpful. She gave me lots of feedback and looked at all of my revised research plans and kept helping me sort out how to do good research. I wouldn't want to take this class with any other prof. Sarah is so good!

(this is for crim 485) AMAZING she truly does everything in her power to make sure all her students succeed and the course itself has so much important information for the workplace highly recommend taking crim485 with her if you can!

I've taken a couple classes with Dawn before and it's clear that she's a very caring professor. However, for CRIM 321 the grading criteria seemed to be unnecessarily harsh. On the exams, there were several trick questions and many marks were taken off of the written section for "missing parts" that were out of the scope of the question.

Not the best lecturer, but a super kind and respectful individual. Dawn cares about her students, and responds to emails and concerns quickly. Papers have clear instructions and grading criteria, exams are pretty straightforward.

A lot of work (multiple assign including an annotated bibliography, letter, + major assignment) but they all fit together. If you keep up with your assignments/readings=manageable. Spend the time on your annotated bib as you'll use it for your other assignments. Rault is knowledgeable/fair. Exams on the harder side. Liked the advocacy letter.

Rault is a great prof but her exams for this class were pretty tough. This class consisted of an annotated bib, an advocacy letter, a major assignment, a midterm, tutorial participation, and a final. Her final, IMO, was very unfair as the short answer portion required cumulative knowledge when she said that exam was non-cumulative.
